Latent Space Diffusion/Flow Models..definition: Variational Autoencoder, a type of generative model that maps visual data from pixel space to a lower-dimensional latent space.
The raw image data represented as pixel values, as opposed to a compressed latent space.
A lower-dimensional representation of visual data, often used in generative models to facilitate training and inference.
Models that learn to generate new data instances that resemble the training data.
Training a model where all components are optimized simultaneously, without intermediate steps or pre-training.

Pixel Space Diffusion/Flow Models..definition: The raw pixel values of an image, as opposed to a latent space representation.
A class of generative models that learn to reverse a diffusion process, gradually transforming noise into an image.
Image generation models that generate images through a sequence of stages, often involving low-resolution generation followed by upscaling.
A technique to enhance the resolution of an image, often used in cascaded models to generate high-resolution images from low-resolution ones.
A type of neural network used for learning latent space representations of data, often used in latent-space image generation models.
A metric used to evaluate the quality of generated images by comparing their feature distributions to those of real images.
A streamlined diffusion framework for high-resolution image synthesis.
A generative model that constructs fractal architectures by recursively invoking atomic generative modules.
A Transformer-based normalizing flow architecture for directly modeling and generating pixels.

3.1 Preliminary: Flow Matching.definition: An algorithm that progressively transforms a sample from a prior distribution to a target data distribution by defining a sequence of linear paths.
A distribution from which samples are initially drawn, often a standard normal distribution.
The distribution that the algorithm aims to transform samples towards.
A Gaussian distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.
A parameter representing the progress along the linear path connecting the prior and target distributions, ranging from 0 to 1.
An equation that defines the velocity of change of a variable with respect to another variable, used here to guide the transformation process.
The rate of change of a sample 𝐱t with respect to time t, approximated by the model during training.
The process of estimating values between known data points, used here to create training examples.
A task where the algorithm transforms one image into another, differing in style or content.

3.2 Multi-Scale Generation in Pixel Spac.definition: A family of image generation models that operate directly in the raw pixel space.
Variational Autoencoder, a pre-trained model that PixelFlow avoids by operating directly in pixel space.
An operation that reduces the resolution of an image, typically by a factor of 2.
An operation that increases the resolution of an image.
The difference between the end and start states in the denoising process, representing the direction of change in the image.
A rescaled value within a stage, used to interpolate between start and end states during training.
A compressed representation of an image, often used in image generation models, which PixelFlow avoids.
The raw pixel values of an image, which PixelFlow operates directly on.
The process of progressively increasing the resolution of an image by removing noise.
A step in the multistage denoising process used by PixelFlow.

3.3 Model Architecture.definition: A neural network architecture known for its simplicity, scalability, and effectiveness in generative modeling.
A specific Transformer-based architecture used as the basis for the implementation of μθ⁢(⋅).
Refers to a large-scale configuration used for the DiT implementation, implying a significant number of parameters and computational resources.
A Variational Autoencoder, a type of model that PixelFlow avoids by operating directly in the raw pixel space.

Patchify..definition: A family of image generation models that operate directly in the raw pixel space.
Variational Autoencoder, a type of neural network used in latent-space models.
A neural network architecture that applies transformer models to image data.
A layer that converts the spatial representation of an image into a sequence of tokens.
A discrete unit of data representing a part of an image, used in transformer models.
A compressed representation of data, often used in generative models like VAEs.
A strategy to concatenate flattened token sequences of varying lengths along the sequence dimension to support efficient attention across multiple resolutions.
Fréchet Inception Distance, a metric used to evaluate the quality of generated images.

RoPE..definition: A family of image generation models that operate directly in the raw pixel space.
Variational Autoencoder, a type of neural network used in latent-space image generation models.
An original positional encoding method replaced by RoPE in PixelFlow.
Rotary Positional Embedding, a positional encoding method known for enabling length extrapolation, particularly in large language models.
An adaptation of RoPE for 2D image data, applying 1D-RoPE independently to the height and width dimensions.
A process observed in the intermediate results of PixelFlow, where noise is progressively removed at various resolution stages.

Resolution Embedding..definition: A family of image generation models that operate directly in the raw pixel space.
An additional signal used to distinguish between different resolutions within the PixelFlow model.
A technique used to encode the resolution signal, inspired by [62].
The output of a convolutional layer, representing extracted image features.
A process of embedding image patches into a feature space.

Text-to-Image Generation..definition: Adaptive layer normalization, a technique for integrating conditioning information in image generation models.
A layer that allows the model to attend to textual input while generating images, aligning visual features with text.
A fundamental building block in the PixelFlow architecture, incorporating self-attention and cross-attention mechanisms.
A large language model used to extract rich text embeddings for conditioning the image generation process.
Numerical representations of text used as input to the image generation model.

3.4 Training and Inference.definition: Variational Autoencoder, a type of neural network used for generative modeling, which PixelFlow avoids by operating directly in pixel space.
A scheme used to uniformly sample training examples from different resolution stages.
A technique that enables joint training of scale-variant examples within a single mini-batch, improving efficiency and scalability.
A standard sampling method used within each resolution stage during inference.
A specific flow-based sampling method, offering a trade-off between speed and accuracy.
Another flow-based sampling method, offering a trade-off between speed and accuracy.
A strategy to mitigate the 'jumping point issue' in multi-scale generation pipelines, ensuring smooth transitions between resolutions.
Generation processes that involve multiple resolution stages.

Kickoff sequence length..definition: A family of image generation models that operate directly in the raw pixel space.
Variational Autoencoder, a type of neural network used for encoding and decoding data.
Fréchet Inception Distance, a metric for evaluating the quality of generated images.
A variant of FID, likely a modified or specialized version of the metric.
Inception Score, another metric used to assess the quality and diversity of generated images.
The initial resolution at which image generation begins.
The size of image blocks processed by the model.
Exponential Moving Average, a technique for stabilizing training by averaging model parameters over time.

Patch size..definition: A family of image generation models that operate directly in the raw pixel space.
The size of the image patches used during the image generation process; affects computational efficiency and performance.
The number of pixels in an image (e.g., 64x64, 256x256).
Fréchet Inception Distance, a metric for evaluating the quality and diversity of generated images.
Likely a variant of FID, used for comparison in the experiments.
Inception Score, another metric for evaluating the quality of generated images.
A metric used to evaluate the quality of generated images.
A metric used to evaluate the quality of generated images.
An algorithm used to solve the equations involved in the image generation process (e.g., Euler, Dopri5).
Classifier-Free Guidance, a technique to improve the quality and controllability of generated images.
The number of times the model processes the training data during the learning process.

4.3 Inference Schedule.definition: The number of iterations performed during the image generation process to refine the image from an initial state to the final output.
A phase in the image generation process where the image is upscaled or refined at a specific resolution.
An algorithm used to numerically solve ordinary differential equations, which are used in PixelFlow to model the flow of pixels during image generation.
A technique used to guide the image generation process by combining the output of a conditional and unconditional model, improving the quality and adherence to the desired conditions.

ODE Solver..definition: A numerical method used to solve ordinary differential equations, crucial for controlling the generative process in PixelFlow.
A first-order numerical method for solving ODEs, known for its simplicity but potentially lower accuracy.
An adaptive, higher-order (Dormand–Prince) numerical method for solving ODEs, offering improved accuracy and stability compared to Euler.
Fréchet Inception Distance, a metric used to evaluate the quality and diversity of generated images by comparing their feature distributions to those of real images.
A variant of FID, often used to assess the quality of generated images in a more sensitive manner.
A metric that measures both the quality and diversity of generated images, based on the output of an Inception network.
In the context of image generation, precision refers to the ability of the model to generate images that accurately reflect the intended semantic content.
In the context of image generation, recall refers to the ability of the model to capture the full range of variations within the intended semantic content.

CFG Schedule..definition: Classifier-Free Guidance, a technique used to guide image generation models.
Fréchet Inception Distance, a metric used to evaluate the quality of generated images by comparing them to a real image dataset.
The raw pixel space refers to operating directly on the pixel values of an image, as opposed to a latent space representation.
A compressed representation of images, often learned by a Variational Autoencoder (VAE), used in some image generation models.
A technique where different CFG values are applied at different stages of the image generation process.
Inception Score, another metric used to evaluate the quality and diversity of generated images.
A metric evaluating the relevance of generated images.
A metric evaluating the completeness of generated images.

Settings..definition: A family of image generation models that operate directly in the raw pixel space.
Variational Autoencoder, a type of neural network architecture often used in latent-space image generation models.
Fréchet Inception Distance, a metric used to evaluate the quality of generated images by comparing them to a set of real images.
A benchmark for evaluating compositional aspects such as coherence and spatial arrangement in text-to-image generation.
A benchmark that assesses alignment between generated images and complex semantic relationships in text.
A benchmark that focuses on complex textual descriptions in text-to-image generation.
A large-scale dataset of images and text used for training image generation models.
A vision-language model used to measure alignment in text-to-image generation benchmarks.
A family of image generation models developed by OpenAI.
Stable Diffusion XL, a powerful text-to-image model.
An image generation model based on the Llama language model.
